image.altText: A young girl wearing a hoodie looks at the camera with teary eyes and dirt on her face, other people in the background

items.synopsis: The Israeli military says it is launching a "precise and targeted operation" inside Gaza's Al-Shifa Hospital. Follow live.

title.children: Israel says it is launching a military 'operation' inside Al-Shifa Hospital

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A White House National Security Council spokesperson says "we don’t want to see a firefight in a hospital" in response to Israel's military operation inside Al-Shifa. "We do not support striking a hospital from the air and we don't want to see a firefight in a hospital where innocent people, helpless people, sick people trying to get medical care they deserve are caught in the crossfire," the spokesperson who did not wished to be named tells Reuters. "Hospitals and patients must be protected." Reporting with Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Hospitals and patients must be protected.': White House National Security Council spokesperson

children.content: A White House National Security Council spokesperson says "we don’t want to see a firefight in a hospital" in response to Israel's military operation inside Al-Shifa.

"We do not support striking a hospital from the air and we don't want to see a firefight in a hospital where innocent people, helpless people, sick people trying to get medical care they deserve are caught in the crossfire," the spokesperson who did not wished to be named tells Reuters.
"Hospitals and patients must be protected."
Reporting with Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israeli tanks have breached the Al-Shifa complex, a journalist inside the hospital told CNN. "We can see them pointing the guns of the tanks toward the hospital. We are not sure whether soldiers are inside the hospital [buildings], but they are inside the complex with the tanks," said Khader Al Za'anoun, a reporter for the Palestinian news agency, Wafa. He said there were exhanges of gunfire in the hospital yard, and some windows of the building were out. The same journalist told the BBC that Israeli soldiers threw a smoke bomb before storming in and entering the hospital's specialised surgical department. Dr Munir al-Bursh, director-general of the Gaza health ministry, told Al Jazeera television that Israeli forces had raided the western side of the medical complex. "There are big explosions and dust entered the areas where we are. We believe an explosion occurred inside the hospital," Dr Bursh said. Israel Defense Forces earlier said it was carrying out a "precise and targeted operation" in Al-Shifa. In its post on X, the IDF also said its forces include "medical teams and Arabic speakers, who have undergone specified training to prepare for this complex and sensitive environment, with the intent that no harm is caused to the civilians being used by Hamas as human shields". Hamas has repeatedly denied that its fighters operate out of hospital grounds.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israeli troops have entered the Al-Shifa hospital complex, eyewitnesses say

children.content: Israeli tanks have breached the Al-Shifa complex,
a journalist inside the hospital told CNN
"We can see them pointing the guns of the tanks toward the hospital. We are not sure whether soldiers are inside the hospital [buildings], but they are inside the complex with the tanks," said
Khader Al Za'anoun
, a reporter for the Palestinian news agency, Wafa.
He said there were exhanges of gunfire in the hospital yard, and some windows of the building were out.
The same journalist
told the BBC
that Israeli soldiers threw a smoke bomb before storming in and entering the hospital's specialised surgical department.
Dr Munir al-Bursh, director-general of the Gaza health ministry, told Al Jazeera television that Israeli forces had raided the western side of the medical complex.
"There are big explosions and dust entered the areas where we are. We believe an explosion occurred inside the hospital," Dr Bursh said.
Israel Defense Forces
earlier said it was carrying out a "precise and targeted operation" in Al-Shifa

In its post on X, the IDF also said its forces include "medical teams and Arabic speakers, who have undergone specified training to prepare for this complex and sensitive environment, with the intent that no harm is caused to the civilians being used by Hamas as human shields".
Hamas has repeatedly denied that its fighters operate out of hospital grounds.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Al-Shifa reportedly houses thousands of civilians, hundreds of patients, and working doctors who "despite their own lives being threatened, haven't left", says ABC's global affairs editor John Lyons. He says an Israeli military operation inside is "the thing so many people have worried about". Israel could also face massive international backlash if they do not find evidence of Hamas tunnels under the hospital, says Lyons. He equates it to the "moment of truth in the information war", adding if Israel does find evidence, "every person in the world will be made aware of that". "The Israelis will want to get those pictures right around the world," Lyons says. "But if there are not, Israel has some really tough questions to answer. "1,000 or so children and babies being killed every week in this war. "Israel is saying some of that has been unavoidable because Hamas has been using civilians to embed themselves. "If they find nothing in the hospital, then a lot of the basis of that argument falls and I think there will be a major backlash against Israel." Watch the full video here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'The moment of truth in the information war is coming now': ABC's global affairs editor John Lyons

children.content: Al-Shifa reportedly houses thousands of civilians, hundreds of patients, and working doctors who "despite their own lives being threatened, haven't left", says ABC's global affairs editor
John Lyons.
He says an Israeli military operation inside is "the thing so many people have worried about".
Israel could also face massive international backlash if they do not find evidence of Hamas tunnels under the hospital, says Lyons.
He equates it to the "moment of truth in the information war", adding if Israel does find evidence, "every person in the world will be made aware of that".
"The Israelis will want to get those pictures right around the world," Lyons says.
"But if there are not, Israel has some really tough questions to answer.
"1,000 or so children and babies being killed every week in this war.
"Israel is saying some of that has been unavoidable because Hamas has been using civilians to embed themselves.
"If they find nothing in the hospital, then a lot of the basis of that argument falls and I think there will be a major backlash against Israel."
Watch the full video here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The push to legalise cannabis for recreational use in Australia just got another boost from a former AFP chief commissioner. At a speech in Melbourne, Mick Palmer AO said cannabis law reform would lead to less discrimination and spending on enforcement. The retired police officer spent many years in the field, including in the Northern Territory, where he says he saw many examples of Indigenous Australians being discriminated against, under laws that once banned them from drinking alcohol. He reminded people listening in the crowd that homosexual acts and suicide had also once been illegal. "Police, too often, in my view, are seen as a ‘cure all’," he said. "The cadre of people most in need of support, treatment and protection are those most likely to be punished. "There has to be a better, more effective, less damaging way to deal with people who use cannabis, than simply arresting them." Palmer was sworn is as the top police officer in the country in 1994 and, during his reign as AFP commissioner, conducted the Palmer Inquiry into the unlawful detention of Australian citizen, Cornelia Rau. He made this speech for one of Australia's most renowned authorities on drug reform. The Penington Institute recently changed its position on cannabis legalisation, and now argues that it should be made lawful in "a strictly regulated market that prioritises safety and health outcomes". "On the basis of long and painful legislative history lessons, it is a position that is hard to argue against," Mr Palmer said. "To do so I suggest, would go a long way towards leaving a truly courageous legacy." The former AFP commissioner's comments come just days after ABC News published a story into the growing push to nationally legalise Australia's most commonly consumed illicit substance. The Greens say legalisation could lead to an economic boom, and medicinal marijuana companies agree, although they are in dispute with the Greens about the best way to achieve this.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Former AFP Commissioner supports cannabis law reform

featuredLink.title: Why marijuana users are worried corporations will replace drug dealers

children.content: The push to legalise cannabis for recreational use in Australia just got another boost from a former AFP chief commissioner.
At a speech in Melbourne, Mick Palmer AO said cannabis law reform would lead to less discrimination and spending on enforcement.

The retired police officer spent many years in the field, including in the Northern Territory, where he says he saw many examples of Indigenous Australians being discriminated against, under laws that once banned them from drinking alcohol.
He reminded people listening in the crowd that homosexual acts and suicide had also once been illegal.
"Police, too often, in my view, are seen as a ‘cure all’," he said.
"The cadre of people most in need of support, treatment and protection are those most likely to be punished.
"There has to be a better, more effective, less damaging way to deal with people who use cannabis, than simply arresting them."

Palmer was sworn is as the top police officer in the country in 1994 and, during his reign as AFP commissioner, conducted the Palmer Inquiry into the unlawful detention of Australian citizen, Cornelia Rau.
He made this speech for one of Australia's most renowned authorities on drug reform.

The Penington Institute recently changed its position on cannabis legalisation, and now argues that it should be made lawful in "a strictly regulated market that prioritises safety and health outcomes".
"On the basis of long and painful legislative history lessons, it is a position that is hard to argue against," Mr Palmer said.
"To do so I suggest, would go a long way towards leaving a truly courageous legacy."
The former AFP commissioner's comments come just days after ABC News published a story into the growing push to nationally legalise Australia's most commonly consumed illicit substance.
The Greens say legalisation could lead to an economic boom, and medicinal marijuana companies agree, although they are in dispute with the Greens about the best way to achieve this.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian shares touched an eight-week high on Wednesday, buoyed by a rally in mining and financial stocks, as falling US inflation data raised bets that the Federal Reserve would not consider hiking interest rates for now. The ASX 200 rose 1.6% to 7,121, by 12:23pm AEDT, its highest level since September 21. The benchmark was also on track for its biggest daily jump since July 13. Rate-pause bets got a boost as data on Tuesday showed US consumer prices were unchanged in October, while underlying inflation rose at the smallest annual pace in two years. In Australia, data showed third-quarter wage price index (seasonally adjusted) rose 4% annually, compared with 3.9% growth expected by a Reuters Poll. Gold stocks soared 3.4% to post their biggest intraday jump since January 4. Northern Star Resources advanced 4% and Evolution Mining surged 4.3%. ASX-listed shares of Newmont Corp rose 3.7%. Miners also climbed 3% to hit a 2-month high, drawing strength from higher iron ore prices as China's stimulus measures for its steel-heavy property sector lifted demand outlook. Rio Tinto jumped 3.4% and BHP Group advanced 2.2%. Rate-sensitive financial stocks extended gains, adding 0.5% and set for their sharpest climb since November 3. Meanwhile, energy stocks bucked the trend, falling by 0.1% as oil prices pared gains on signs tensions in the Middle East could be easing and uncertainty about US oil inventories. Heavyweights Santos fell 0.6%, while Woodside Energy was flat. Leading gains on the benchmark, Centuria Capital Group jumped 11% after the specialist investment manager secured $500 million institutional industrial funding.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX still tracking higher in afternoon trade

children.content: Australian shares touched an eight-week high on Wednesday, buoyed by a rally in mining and financial stocks, as falling US inflation data raised bets that the Federal Reserve would not consider hiking interest rates for now.
The ASX 200 rose 1.6% to 7,121, by 12:23pm AEDT, its highest level since September 21. The benchmark was also on track for its biggest daily jump since July 13.
Rate-pause bets got a boost as data on Tuesday showed US consumer prices were unchanged in October, while underlying inflation rose at the smallest annual pace in two years.
In Australia, data showed third-quarter wage price index (seasonally adjusted) rose 4% annually, compared with 3.9% growth expected by a Reuters Poll.
Gold stocks soared 3.4% to post their biggest intraday jump since January 4.
Northern Star Resources advanced 4% and Evolution Mining surged 4.3%. ASX-listed shares of Newmont Corp rose 3.7%.
Miners also climbed 3% to hit a 2-month high, drawing strength from higher iron ore prices as China's stimulus measures for its steel-heavy property sector lifted demand outlook.
Rio Tinto jumped 3.4% and BHP Group advanced 2.2%.
Rate-sensitive financial stocks extended gains, adding 0.5% and set for their sharpest climb since November 3.
Meanwhile, energy stocks bucked the trend, falling by 0.1% as oil prices pared gains on signs tensions in the Middle East could be easing and uncertainty about US oil inventories.
Heavyweights Santos fell 0.6%, while Woodside Energy was flat.
Leading gains on the benchmark, Centuria Capital Group jumped 11% after the specialist investment manager secured $500 million institutional industrial funding.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Wages grew 1.3 per cent over the September quarter, which is the biggest increase in the 26-year history of the ABS Wage Price Index. Wages were pushed higher by a 5.75 per cent boost for workers on awards and a 15 per cent pay jump for many aged care workers from July 1. Annual wages growth was 4 per cent, which was the strongest since March 2009, but roughly in line with current Reserve Bank forecasts. Read more from business reporter Michael Janda .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Wages growth fastest on record in Q3

featuredLink.title: Wages growth fastest on record as aged care, award boosts lift pay rates

children.content: Wages grew 1.3 per cent over the September quarter, which is the biggest increase in the 26-year history of the ABS Wage Price Index.
Wages were pushed higher by a 5.75 per cent boost for workers on awards and a 15 per cent pay jump for many aged care workers from July 1.
Annual wages growth was 4 per cent, which was the strongest since March 2009, but roughly in line with current Reserve Bank forecasts.
Read more from business reporter
Michael Janda
